item.title: Portugal Elects a President, With Leftist Beating a Surging Far Right
item.description: Despite a decisive victory for António José Seguro, a nationalist’s presence in the runoff showed that Portugal is not immune to Europe’s rising far-right tide.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Patricia De Melo Moreira/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: António José Seguro, who decisively won Portugal’s presidential election, on Sunday evening.

item.title: Japan’s Sanae Takaichi Wins Snap Election in a Landslide
item.description: Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi won a sweeping mandate from voters for her economic agenda and tough stances on immigration and China.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández, River Akira Davis, Kiuko Notoya and Hisako Ueno
item.media:description: Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi of Japan received a resounding mandate for her economic policies and tough stance on immigration and China after snap elections on Sunday.

item.title: Iranian Nobel Laureate Gets Second Prison Sentence and Ends Hunger Strike
item.description: The activist Narges Mohammadi was sentenced to another seven years, bringing the total she must serve to 17 years, her foundation said.
item.dc:creator: Sanam Mahoozi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Narges Mohammadi Foundation, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Narges Mohammadi in an undated photo provided by her foundation in 2023.

item.title: Thailand’s Conservative Party Claims Surprise Election Victory
item.description: It was the first time in years that a conservative party preaching nationalism, patriotism and respect for the monarchy came out on top.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: Anutin Charnvirakul, the leader of the conservative Bhumjaithai Party, in Bangkok on Sunday.

item.title: Starmer’s Chief of Staff Resigns, Citing Role in Hiring Friend of Epstein
item.description: The Labour official was ensnared in a scandal after helping appoint Peter Mandelson as Britain’s ambassador to the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: Morgan McSweeney in December. He served as Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s chief of staff until Sunday.

item.title: Cuba’s Communist Government Has Lasted 67 Years. Will It Fall Under Trump?
item.description: The Trump administration, which has tightened the U.S. chokehold on Cuba by cutting off foreign oil, is betting that this is the Cuban communist revolution’s last year.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles and David C. Adams
item.media:description: Fidel Castro, who led Cuba from the 1959 revolution until he formally stepped down in 2008, speaking in Santa Maria Del Mar in 1964.

item.title: At the Winter Olympics, Team USA Can’t Escape the Politics at Home
item.description: A backlash to Trump administration policies has followed U.S. athletes to Italy. One skier’s comments drew a furious response from the president himself.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich, Tariq Panja, Heather Knight and Juliet Macur
item.media:description: Politics inevitably encroaches on the Olympics, despite the International Olympic Committee’s best efforts to cast the Games as an athletic interlude free from conflict.

item.title: Japan’s Leader Is Set for a Big Election Win. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: Sanae Takaichi, who has proved popular as the first woman to lead Japan as prime minister, was on course for a sweeping mandate after a snap election on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:description: Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi standing atop a vehicle during an election campaign in Tokyo on Saturday.

item.title: A Curling Champion Is Italy’s Hometown Hero at the Olympic Games
item.description: Stefania Constantini worked in a clothes shop until her sports career took off. The champion curler is now one of Italy’s best hopes at the Winter Games.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stefania Constantini practicing before a mixed doubles curling match between Italy and South Korea on Thursday in Cortina d’Ampezzo, Italy.

item.title: In Bid to Lead Thailand, a Progressive Party Softens Its Image
item.description: Sunday’s election is a test for the progressive, pro-democracy movement in Thailand, which has been blocked from taking power despite success at the polls.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Kittiphum Sringammuang
item.media:description: Natthaphong Ruengpanyawut, the leader of the People’s Party, speaking to supporters in Bangkok on Friday.

item.title: Trump Reverts to Diplomacy With Iran, but the Road Is Narrow
item.description: Iran is skilled at prolonging negotiations over its nuclear program, and seems to be hoping President Trump is out for a quick win, rather than a prolonged regional war.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Omani Foreign Ministry, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Steve Witkoff, President Trump’s special envoy, center, and Jared Kushner, the president’s son-in-law, with Oman’s foreign minister, Badr Albusaidi, in a photograph released on Friday by Oman’s Foreign Ministry.

item.title: What to Know About Thailand’s Election
item.description: The progressive People’s Party was leading in surveys conducted before Sunday’s election, but the country has a history of overturning voters’ will.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: A polling station on Sunday in Bangkok during Thailand’s general election.

item.title: Trump’s ‘Board of Peace’ Sets Date to Meet in Washington, Officials Say
item.description: The group, which has prompted skepticism from some U.S. allies, is scheduled to meet on Feb. 19, according to the officials.
item.dc:creator: Natan Odenheimer
item.media:description: President Trump during a Board of Peace event at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, last month.

item.title: Trump’s Greenland Threats Rattle the Faroe Islands
item.description: Many people in the Faroe Islands, a tiny archipelago in the North Atlantic, want to be their own state. The crisis over Greenland, Denmark’s other territory, has complicated that, for now.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg, Jeffrey Gettleman, Regin Winther Poulsen and Sergey Ponomarev
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times

item.title: Five Years After Myanmar Coup, ‘Even Hope Has Become a Risk’
item.description: The country’s cities have been spared the violence of a hard-fought civil war. But as the economy has hollowed out, many urbanites have become desperate.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock and Lauren DeCicca
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: The downtown of Yangon, Myanmar’s largest city. Urban areas in the country have been plagued by issues like soaring inflation, high unemployment and shortages of goods.

item.title: In Pakistan, a Kite Festival Returns to Troubled Skies
item.description: The vibrant celebration, banned for two decades, brightened the eastern city of Lahore, where residents face alarming levels of air pollution and political restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier, Zia ur-Rehman and Saiyna Bashir
item.media:credit: Saiyna Bashir for The New York Times

item.title: After M23 Takeover, Goma Carries Violent Memories and Signs of Hope
item.description: A year after a rebel takeover, residents of Goma, in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo, carry violent memories and signs of hope.
item.dc:creator: Guerchom Ndebo
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: One year ago, M23, a rebel militia, violently charged into the city of Goma in the Democratic Republic of Congo and took it over from the government.

item.title: Jimmy Lai’s 20-Year Term Follows a Familiar Chinese Pattern
item.description: The heavy sentence for the Hong Kong publisher aligns with mainland cases where influential critics of the Communist Party have been sent to prison for many years.
item.dc:creator: Lily Kuo
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Lai has been held in solitary confinement for more than 1,800 days.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: Mr. Lai walking through the Stanley Prison in Hong Kong in 2023.

item.title: Jimmy Lai’s children have led a global campaign for him.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:description: Sebastian Lai, center, son of Jimmy Lai, held a news conference outside Downing Street in London last year.

item.title: Jimmy Lai’s conviction was years in the making.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: Jimmy Lai was arrested under the national security law in Hong Kong in 2020.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Francesca Regalado

item.title: Venezuela Frees Key Opposition Figures as Government Courts U.S. Support
item.description: Hours after the release of at least 35 political prisoners, the most prominent one was “kidnapped” by armed men, according to relatives.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Juan Pablo Guanipa, center, a Venezuelan opposition politician, outside El Helicoide detention center in Caracas after his release on Sunday.

item.title: How Ilia Malinin and Team U.S.A. Held Off Japan to Win Gold Medal
item.description: And summary goes here
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather and Photos by Vincent Alban

item.title: On the Brink of a New Arms Race
item.description: For the first time in decades, the U.S. and Russia no longer have a nuclear arms control agreement.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Takaichi is poised to push Japan further to the right.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:description: Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi of Japan is poised to push the country even further to the right on issues like immigration, defense and the economy.

item.title: Breezy Johnson’s Olympic Gold Medal Celebration Muted By Lindsey Vonn’s Crash
item.description: Johnson won her first Olympic gold medal after her teammate Vonn crashed early in her run.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather and James Hill
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times

item.title: Heavy Snow Disrupts Japan Election, Forcing Polling Stations to Close Early
item.description: The government said that about 40 percent of all polling stations closed earlier than planned because of heavy snow on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Kiuko Notoya, Hisako Ueno and Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: People walking past campaign posters in Tokyo on Sunday.

item.title: Shortages of posters and trucks add to candidates’ challenges.
item.description: Japn
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:description: Ryuichi Yoneyama, a candidate from the Centrist Reform Alliance, campaigned for Japan’s lower house election in Nagaoka on Saturday.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández, River Akira Davis, Kiuko Notoya and Hisako Ueno

item.title: China’s Presence Looms Large in Japan’s Election
item.description: Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi’s handling of bilateral relations has become a campaign issue. Her earlier comments on Taiwan brought reprisals from Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:credit: Jiji Press, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi of Japan shaking hands with President Xi Jinping of China on the sidelines of a summit in Gyeongju, Korea, last October.

item.title: Trump’s Oil Grab in Venezuela Shatters an American Taboo
item.description: U.S. presidents have long been accused of plotting to control foreign oil. But President Trump has asserted a U.S. right to take it.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Venezuela’s Cardon oil refinery. Critics say President Trump’s plan for the country’s oil industry revives bitter memories of colonial exploitation and flagrantly violates international law.

item.title: 6 Fishermen Reel In a 244-Pound Atlantic Halibut, Setting a Local Record
item.description: The fish, hooked as part of a study on the halibut population around the Ha! Ha! Bay in the Canadian province of Quebec, measured more than 6.5 feet long, researchers said.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker

item.title: Ilia Malinin, the ‘Quad God,’ leaves an ace up his sleeve.
item.description: Summary
item.dc:creator: Sam Manchester and Photos by Vincent Alban

item.title: Saudis Announce New Investments in Syria, a Sign of Deepening Ties
item.description: Saudi and Syrian officials announced deals ranging from aviation to telecommunications, offering a much-needed boost to Syria’s battered economy.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Construction workers repairing a section of castle walls inside the citadel of Aleppo, Syria, in August. The deals announced on Saturday include the rehabilitation of the city’s airport.

item.title: Roland Huntford, Lore-Debunking Historian of Polar Exploration, Dies at 98
item.description: He caused an uproar by challenging the heroic status of Robert Falcon Scott, the Briton who led a doomed quest to the South Pole in 1912.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Roland Huntford in 2008. South African by birth, he nevertheless spoke Norwegian fluently and spent 15 years as the Scandinavian correspondent for The Observer, a British newspaper, developing a keen interest in polar expeditions.

item.title: A Mosque Bombing Undercuts Pakistan’s Bid for Security
item.description: Pakistan has made headway against the Islamic State and other militants, but a bloody suicide attack showed how fragile its progress has been.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:description: A funeral on Saturday for victims of a suicide bombing at a mosque on the outskirts of Islamabad, Pakistan, the day before. The attack killed at least 31 people.

item.title: Russian Strikes Pummel Ukraine’s Power Grid
item.description: The drone and missile bombardments were the latest attacks on Ukrainian energy infrastructure during a winter freeze, as peace talks have made little progress.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:description: Sheltering in a metro station in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Saturday. Damage from overnight strikes prompted the Ukrainian government to request emergency electricity assistance from Poland.

item.title: Vanity Fair
item.description: Behind the scenes at the Westminster Dog Show, the entrants were affectionate. Or at least they acted like it.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: At the Olympics, the Canada-U.S. Hockey Rivalry Heats Up
item.description: Beating America has always felt good, especially on the ice. Since President Trump began issuing tariffs and threats against Canada, sports feels extra personal.
item.dc:creator: Shawna Richer
item.media:description: Canadian athletes during the opening ceremony at Livigno Snow Park on Friday.

item.title: These Mathematicians Are Trying to Educate A.I.
item.description: Large language models struggle to solve research-level math questions. It takes a human to assess just how poorly they perform.
item.dc:creator: Siobhan Roberts
item.media:credit: Aurelien Bergot for The New York Times
item.media:description: Martin Hairer, a mathematician at the Swiss Federal Technology Institute of Lausanne. He splits his time between there and the Imperial College London.

item.title: Olympics Officials Signal Sanctions on Russia in Sports May End
item.description: In Milan this week, Olympics officials signaled a willingness to ease years of restrictions imposed on the country over its state-backed doping program and invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Athletes competing for the Russian Olympic Committee in the men’s ice hockey gold medal match at the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing. The team won a silver medal.

item.title: Philippe Morillon, General Who Made Fateful Protection Promise, Dies at 90
item.description: “I will never abandon you,” he told residents of Srebrenica amid sectarian armed conflict in Bosnia. The town later suffered the worst massacre in Europe since World War II.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia
item.media:description: Gen. Philippe Morillon in 1993, as commander of U.N. forces in what was then Bosnia-Herzegovina.

item.title: How Is Security Different at These Olympic Games?
item.description: Our sports correspondent Tariq Panja talks with Katrin Bennhold about the security at the Olympics in Italy, including the presence of Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents, who the U.S. says are there only in an advisory role.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja, Katrin Bennhold, Leila Medina and Laura Salaberry

item.title: JD Vance Is Booed at Winter Olympics Opening Ceremony in Milan
item.description: Before the event, protesters marched in Milan in opposition to U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, whose personnel are in Italy to advise local officials in securing the Winter Games.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn
item.media:description: Vice President JD Vance and Usha Vance at San Siro stadium for the opening ceremony of the Winter Olympics in Milan on Friday.

item.title: Haiti Reaches ‘Full Crisis’ as Transition Government Expires
item.description: The tenure of a presidential council that has been running Haiti expires on Saturday. It’s unclear what will come next.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles, David C. Adams and André Paultre
item.media:description: A view from inside an armored police vehicle showing cars burned by armed gangs and used as a barricade on a deserted street Port-au-Prince, Haiti, last month.

item.title: Saalumarada Thimmakka Dies; Planted and Nurtured Thousands of Trees
item.description: Believed to be 113, she spent decades building an environmental legacy in India, inspired by her grief at being unable to conceive children.
item.dc:creator: Pragati K.B.

item.title: A dozen U.S. figure skaters march in the ceremony, some fresh off competing.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.media:description: Alysa Liu, the reigning world champion, is among the members of the U.S. Figure Skating team marching in the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games.

item.title: The U.S. flag bearers are a renowned speedskater and a bobsledder, both previous Olympians.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur

item.title: France and Canada Open Consulates in Greenland, Following Trump Threats
item.description: Greenland’s mini diplomatic scene is about to get more lively as Canada and France set up consulates, following threats by President Trump to take over the island.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Maya Tekeli
item.media:description: The opening of the Canadian Consulate in a building shared with the Icelandic consulate in Nuuk, Greenland, on Friday.

item.title: Flying Solo: Some Olympic Athletes Are Their Country’s Whole Team
item.description: At the Winter Games, athletes from 15 different nations are the only competitor from their countries.
item.dc:creator: Heather Knight
item.media:description: Four years ago, at age 17, Aruwin Salehhuddin became the first female athlete to represent Malaysia at the Olympics. But there was a male athlete, too, and they carried the flag together. This year, she will be carrying it alone.

item.title: Haiti Just Won the Fashion Game at the Opening Ceremonies
item.description: The athletes from the Caribbean nation wanted their appearances to honor their country’s heritage. The result is looks that stand out.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:description: Stella Jean, center, a Haitian-Italian designer based in Milan, designed the looks of Haiti’s national team.

item.title: In Talks, Trump Won’t Allow Iran to Have Any Enriched Uranium
item.description: Can the two sides get past Iran’s claim that it has a “right” to enrich uranium?
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Workers at a uranium conversion facility in Isfahan, Iran, in 2005. Analysts say Iran’s position on enrichment reflects the country’s intense pride in a nuclear program that has become a symbol of Iranian independence.

item.title: The ghost of Giorgio Armani hovers over the Games.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:description: Three lines of models in red, white and green Armani looks walking the stadium “runway” during the opening ceremonies.

item.title: China Reverses Death Sentence for Canadian in a Small Win for Carney
item.description: The ruling by China’s highest court followed a recent meeting between China and Canada’s top leaders that led to a thaw in the two countries’ relations.
item.dc:creator: Lily Kuo
item.media:credit: Intermediate Peoples' Court of Dalian, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Robert Lloyd Schellenberg in 2019 during his retrial on drug-trafficking charges in a court in Dalian, China.

item.title: Scattered protests occur in Milan before the ceremonies begin.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn and Tariq Panja
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the hours leading up to the Winter Games, demonstrators protesting in the San Siro district of Milan.

item.title: 2026 Winter Olympics Opening Ceremonies Performers: Mariah Carey, Andrea Bocelli and More
item.description: The performers include an Italian tenor who is one of the most successful singers in the world and an actress who has had roles in “The White Lotus” and “The Paper.”
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather and Joshua Barone

item.title: Mariah Carey Performs at Winter Olympics Opening Ceremony in Milan
item.description: The singer-songwriter “perfectly embodies the emotional spirit of the Games,” Olympic organizers said.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz, Victor Mather and Alex Marshall
item.media:description: Mariah Carey is one of the best-selling recording artists of all time.

item.title: Who will light the Olympic cauldrons?
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather

item.title: No Fashion Focus in Milan After France Made It Part of Summer Olympics
item.description: In Paris, the fashion powerhouse LVMH was a headline sponsor and helped design the medals and the athletes’ apparel.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.category: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton SA
item.media:description: Lady Gaga performing before the opening ceremony of the Paris Olympic Games.

item.title: Milan Athletes Welcome Return of Winter Olympics Spectators
item.description: At the last Winter Games, in 2022 in Beijing, the coronavirus pandemic meant that spectators were largely absent and competing was a lonely experience.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Empty seats at the speedskating finals during the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing.

item.title: A Lightweight, Minimalist Torch Design Helps Kick Off the Winter Games
item.description: The opening ceremonies will also have two cauldron lightings for the first time. One will be in Milan, the other in Cortina d’Ampezzo.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Italian ballet dancer Roberto Bolle receiving the Olympic torch in Milan on Friday. The torch passed through some 300 towns and more than 60 UNESCO World Heritage Sites.
